**Transcript**:
Anything we ever achieved started with someone
imagining it first. So if we can’t imagine a way out of the climate
crisis it just can’t happen. We know that the crisis is getting worse every,
single, day and many of us are losing hope for our future. But despair is not an option. We must rise up meet the greatest challenge
of our lives with stubborn optimism. And imagining is the first step So, are you ready to imagine? In this critical decade The biggest tree-planting campaign in history
is sucking billions of tons of carbon out of the air. And forests and indigenous lands? They’re protected! This is what your city looks like...it’s
green. I mean, everywhere. Streets are pedestrian and kid friendly. Food growing on rooftops, in car parks, which
by the way, we don’t need any more, because we don’t own cars any more. And here’s something Birds Can you imagine your city as a sanctuary for
nature and wildlife?! There are solar panels on every rooftop across the globe. Clean, interconnected energy lights every
home, every clinic, every school. We no longer choke on the toxic fumes of fossil
fuels. It’s not hard to imagine. This technology already exists! And what about the millions of new jobs created? Are you picturing it? Really picturing it. Roads? They are green too. Traffic’s cut right down
Public transport everywhere is electric, dependable - and free. Can you smell the air? Clean. Farming? All regenerative. Which means healthy soil and better food. And we don’t eat much meat. Can you imagine what we could do with a third
of the world’s crop land currently used to grow animal feed? Here’s something to imagine:
Fields of seaweed, miles long, grown in oceans across the planet.
They draw down billions of tons of carbon, restore sea life, and guess what, they’re
a limitless source of protein rich food. And we can do so much more. Re-wild our land. Protect our cities from rising sea levels. Restore coral reefs. These things we are imagining? They are all possible now, just with technology
that’s available today. We are the last generation that can prevent
catastrophic, run-away climate change. We cannot give up! Anything we ever achieved started with
someone imagining it first. This is the decade to make this imagined future
happen. Share this video and help those around you
have the courage to imagine it too.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When imagining a world where climate change is not a big issue, there will be many trees. Why?
Options: A. Forests will have to be preserved for carbon removal, B. Forests will be preserved for indigenous people, C. Forests provide a habitat for organisms, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the first step in addressing the climate crisis, according to the transcript? Options: A. Implementing existing technology, B. Imagining a way out of the crisis, C. Planting trees, D. Reducing fossil fuel use Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the city envisioned in the transcript. Options: A. A city with increased car ownership and parking spaces, B. A city with green spaces, pedestrian-friendly streets, and food growing on rooftops, C. A city with reduced public transportation, D. A city with more fossil fuel-based energy Correct Option: B
Question 3: A local government wants to reduce carbon emissions in their city. Which of the following initiatives, inspired by the transcript, could they implement? Options: A. Increase parking spaces and encourage car ownership, B. Promote electric public transportation and pedestrian-friendly streets, C. Reduce funding for renewable energy, D. Cut down trees in urban areas Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the relationship between the imagined future and technology, according to the transcript? Options: A. The imagined future requires technology that has not yet been invented, B. The imagined future is only possible with a significant reduction in technology use, C. The imagined future is possible with technology that is already available today, D. The imagined future has no connection to technology Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is one potential benefit of growing fields of seaweed in oceans, according to the transcript? Options: A. Reduced sea life, B. Increased carbon emissions, C. A limitless source of protein-rich food, D. Decreased crop land for animal feed Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the consequence of not taking action to address the climate crisis, according to the transcript? Options: A. A gradual improvement in the environment, B. A reduction in carbon emissions, C. Catastrophic, runaway climate change, D. No significant impact on the environment Correct Option: C
Question 7: How does the transcript suggest we can use the world's crop land more efficiently? Options: A. By increasing meat consumption, B. By using a third of the world's crop land for purposes other than growing animal feed, C. By reducing the use of regenerative farming practices, D. By increasing the use of fossil fuels in farming Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is one way to protect cities from rising sea levels, according to the transcript? Options: A. By reducing the use of renewable energy, B. By increasing car ownership, C. By re-wilding our land and restoring coral reefs, D. By promoting non-regenerative farming practices Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the role of imagination in addressing the climate crisis, according to the transcript? Options: A. Imagination is not necessary for addressing the climate crisis, B. Imagination is only necessary for implementing existing technology, C. Imagination is the first step in addressing the climate crisis, D. Imagination is only necessary for reducing fossil fuel use Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the call to action at the end of the transcript? Options: A. Share the video and encourage others to give up on addressing the climate crisis, B. Share the video and help others have the courage to imagine a better future, C. Reduce the use of renewable energy, D. Increase car ownership and fossil fuel use Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although Question 2 does not directly ask about trees, it does describe the city envisioned in the transcript, which includes green spaces. The correct option (B) mentions "a city with green spaces, pedestrian-friendly streets, and food growing on rooftops." This aligns with the ground truth MCQ's focus on the importance of trees and forests in a world where climate change is not a big issue.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. The generated MCQs focus more on the city's overall environment and green spaces, whereas the ground truth MCQ specifically asks about the importance of trees and forests for carbon removal, indigenous people, and providing habitats for organisms.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the provided options, I would choose Question 2, but I would recommend creating a new generated MCQ that more closely matches the ground truth MCQ's content and intent.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Anything we ever achieved started with someone
imagining it first. So if we can’t imagine a way out of the climate
crisis it just can’t happen. We know that the crisis is getting worse every,
single, day and many of us are losing hope for our future. But despair is not an option. We must rise up meet the greatest challenge
of our lives with stubborn optimism. And imagining is the first step So, are you ready to imagine? In this critical decade The biggest tree-planting campaign in history
is sucking billions of tons of carbon out of the air. And forests and indigenous lands? They’re protected! This is what your city looks like...it’s
green. I mean, everywhere. Streets are pedestrian and kid friendly. Food growing on rooftops, in car parks, which
by the way, we don’t need any more, because we don’t own cars any more. And here’s something Birds Can you imagine your city as a sanctuary for
nature and wildlife?! There are solar panels on every rooftop across the globe. Clean, interconnected energy lights every
home, every clinic, every school. We no longer choke on the toxic fumes of fossil
fuels. It’s not hard to imagine. This technology already exists! And what about the millions of new jobs created? Are you picturing it? Really picturing it. Roads? They are green too. Traffic’s cut right down
Public transport everywhere is electric, dependable - and free. Can you smell the air? Clean. Farming? All regenerative. Which means healthy soil and better food. And we don’t eat much meat. Can you imagine what we could do with a third
of the world’s crop land currently used to grow animal feed? Here’s something to imagine:
Fields of seaweed, miles long, grown in oceans across the planet.
They draw down billions of tons of carbon, restore sea life, and guess what, they’re
a limitless source of protein rich food. And we can do so much more. Re-wild our land. Protect our cities from rising sea levels. Restore coral reefs. These things we are imagining? They are all possible now, just with technology
that’s available today. We are the last generation that can prevent
catastrophic, run-away climate change. We cannot give up! Anything we ever achieved started with
someone imagining it first. This is the decade to make this imagined future
happen. Share this video and help those around you
have the courage to imagine it too.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In our imagined world, streets will be pedestrian friendly, why?
Options: A. Food will be growing along them, B. Walking decreases your carbon footprint, C. People do not own cars anymore, D. Both b and c, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At roughly 4pm on July 20, 1969, mankind was just minutes away 
from landing on the surface of the moon. But before the astronauts 
began their final descent, an emergency alarm lit up. Something was overloading 
the computer, and threatened to abort the landing. Back on Earth, Margaret Hamilton 
held her breath. She'd led the team developing 
the pioneering in-flight software, so she knew this mission 
had no room for error. But the nature 
of this last-second emergency would soon prove her software 
was working exactly as planned. Born 33 years earlier in Paoli, Indiana, 
Hamilton had always been inquisitive. In college, she studied mathematics
and philosophy, before taking a research position at the 
Massachusetts Institute of Technology to pay for grad school. Here, she encountered her first computer
while developing software to support research 
into the new field of chaos theory. Next at MIT's Lincoln Laboratory, Hamilton developed software 
for America’s first air defense system to search for enemy aircraft. But when she heard 
that renowned engineer Charles Draper was looking for help 
sending mankind to the moon, she immediately joined his team. NASA looked to Draper and his group 
of over 400 engineers to invent the first compact 
digital flight computer, the Apollo Guidance Computer. Using input from astronauts, this device would be responsible 
for guiding, navigating and controlling the spacecraft. At a time when unreliable computers 
filled entire rooms, the AGC needed to operate 
without any errors, and fit in one cubic foot of space. Draper divided the lab into two teams, one for designing hardware 
and one for developing software. Hamilton led the team that built 
the on-board flight software for both the Command and Lunar Modules. This work, for which she coined the term
“software engineering," was incredibly high stakes. Human lives were on the line, 
so every program had to be perfect. Margaret’s software needed to quickly
detect unexpected errors and recover from them in real time. But this kind of adaptable program 
was difficult to build, since early software could only process 
jobs in a predetermined order. To solve this problem, Margaret designed her program 
to be “asynchronous,” meaning the software's more important
jobs would interrupt less important ones. Her team assigned every task 
a unique priority to ensure that each job 
occurred in the correct order and at the right time—
regardless of any surprises. After this breakthrough, Margaret realized her software 
could help the astronauts work in an asynchronous environment as well. She designed Priority Displays that would interrupt 
astronaut’s regularly scheduled tasks to warn them of emergencies. The astronaut could then communicate
with Mission Control to determine the best path forward. This marked the first time flight software
communicated directly— and asynchronously— 
with a pilot. It was these fail safes that triggered 
the alarms just before the lunar landing. Buzz Aldrin quickly realized his mistake— he’d inadvertently flipped 
the rendezvous radar switch. This radar would be essential 
on their journey home, but here it was using up 
vital computational resources. Fortunately, the Apollo Guidance Computer
was well equipped to manage this. During the overload, 
the software restart programs allowed only the highest priority jobs 
to be processed— including the programs 
necessary for landing. The Priority Displays 
gave the astronauts a choice— to land or not to land. With minutes to spare, 
Mission Control gave the order. The Apollo 11 landing was about 
the astronauts, Mission Control, software and hardware all working together
as an integrated system of systems. Hamilton’s contributions were essential
to the work of engineers and scientists inspired by President John F. Kennedy’s 
goal to reach the Moon. And her life-saving work 
went far beyond Apollo 11— no bugs were ever found in the in-flight
software for any crewed Apollo missions. After her work on Apollo, Hamilton founded a company that uses 
its unique universal systems language to create breakthroughs 
for systems and software. In 2003, NASA honored her achievements 
with the largest financial award they’d ever given to an individual. And 47 years after her software
first guided astronauts to the moon, Hamilton was awarded 
the Presidential Medal of Freedom for changing the way we think 
about technology.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Margaret’s Hamilton was born in ________, ________.
Options: A. Akron, Ohio, B. Detroit, Michigan, C. Erie, Indiana, D. Paoli, Indiana
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Margaret Hamilton born? Options: A. Paoli, Indiana, B. Massachusetts, C. New York, D. California Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the main challenge Margaret Hamilton's team faced while developing the on-board flight software for the Apollo Guidance Computer? Options: A. To make the software user-friendly for astronauts, B. To ensure the software operated without errors and fit in a limited space, C. To develop software that could process jobs in a predetermined order, D. To create software that could only detect expected errors Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did Margaret Hamilton's software handle unexpected errors? Options: A. By processing jobs in a predetermined order, B. By restarting the entire system, C. By quickly detecting and recovering from them in real-time, D. By ignoring them Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the term coined by Margaret Hamilton for her work on the Apollo Guidance Computer software? Options: A. Software Development, B. Software Engineering, C. Computer Science, D. Systems Analysis Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the cause of the emergency alarm that lit up just before the lunar landing? Options: A. A malfunction in the Apollo Guidance Computer, B. A mistake made by Mission Control, C. Buzz Aldrin inadvertently flipping the rendezvous radar switch, D. A failure in the spacecraft's navigation system Correct Option: C
Question 6: How did the Apollo Guidance Computer manage the overload caused by the rendezvous radar switch? Options: A. By shutting down the entire system, B. By allowing only the highest priority jobs to be processed, C. By ignoring the overload, D. By restarting the system manually Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the significance of Margaret Hamilton's Priority Displays in the Apollo Guidance Computer software? Options: A. They provided astronauts with a list of scheduled tasks, B. They warned astronauts of emergencies and allowed them to communicate with Mission Control, C. They displayed the spacecraft's navigation data, D. They controlled the spacecraft's altitude Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the outcome of Margaret Hamilton's work on the Apollo Guidance Computer software? Options: A. The software was never used in any crewed Apollo missions, B. The software was found to have several bugs, C. No bugs were ever found in the in-flight software for any crewed Apollo missions, D. The software was only used in the Apollo 11 mission Correct Option: C
Question 9: How did Margaret Hamilton's work on the Apollo Guidance Computer software contribute to the success of the Apollo 11 mission? Options: A. Her software ensured the spacecraft's navigation system functioned correctly, B. Her software managed the overload caused by the rendezvous radar switch, allowing the mission to proceed, C. Her software provided astronauts with a list of scheduled tasks, D. Her software controlled the spacecraft's altitude Correct Option: B
Question 10: What award did Margaret Hamilton receive in 2016 for her contributions to the field of technology? Options: A. Presidential Medal of Freedom, B. NASA Exceptional Service Medal, C. National Medal of Technology, D. Draper Prize Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At roughly 4pm on July 20, 1969, mankind was just minutes away 
from landing on the surface of the moon. But before the astronauts 
began their final descent, an emergency alarm lit up. Something was overloading 
the computer, and threatened to abort the landing. Back on Earth, Margaret Hamilton 
held her breath. She'd led the team developing 
the pioneering in-flight software, so she knew this mission 
had no room for error. But the nature 
of this last-second emergency would soon prove her software 
was working exactly as planned. Born 33 years earlier in Paoli, Indiana, 
Hamilton had always been inquisitive. In college, she studied mathematics
and philosophy, before taking a research position at the 
Massachusetts Institute of Technology to pay for grad school. Here, she encountered her first computer
while developing software to support research 
into the new field of chaos theory. Next at MIT's Lincoln Laboratory, Hamilton developed software 
for America’s first air defense system to search for enemy aircraft. But when she heard 
that renowned engineer Charles Draper was looking for help 
sending mankind to the moon, she immediately joined his team. NASA looked to Draper and his group 
of over 400 engineers to invent the first compact 
digital flight computer, the Apollo Guidance Computer. Using input from astronauts, this device would be responsible 
for guiding, navigating and controlling the spacecraft. At a time when unreliable computers 
filled entire rooms, the AGC needed to operate 
without any errors, and fit in one cubic foot of space. Draper divided the lab into two teams, one for designing hardware 
and one for developing software. Hamilton led the team that built 
the on-board flight software for both the Command and Lunar Modules. This work, for which she coined the term
“software engineering," was incredibly high stakes. Human lives were on the line, 
so every program had to be perfect. Margaret’s software needed to quickly
detect unexpected errors and recover from them in real time. But this kind of adaptable program 
was difficult to build, since early software could only process 
jobs in a predetermined order. To solve this problem, Margaret designed her program 
to be “asynchronous,” meaning the software's more important
jobs would interrupt less important ones. Her team assigned every task 
a unique priority to ensure that each job 
occurred in the correct order and at the right time—
regardless of any surprises. After this breakthrough, Margaret realized her software 
could help the astronauts work in an asynchronous environment as well. She designed Priority Displays that would interrupt 
astronaut’s regularly scheduled tasks to warn them of emergencies. The astronaut could then communicate
with Mission Control to determine the best path forward. This marked the first time flight software
communicated directly— and asynchronously— 
with a pilot. It was these fail safes that triggered 
the alarms just before the lunar landing. Buzz Aldrin quickly realized his mistake— he’d inadvertently flipped 
the rendezvous radar switch. This radar would be essential 
on their journey home, but here it was using up 
vital computational resources. Fortunately, the Apollo Guidance Computer
was well equipped to manage this. During the overload, 
the software restart programs allowed only the highest priority jobs 
to be processed— including the programs 
necessary for landing. The Priority Displays 
gave the astronauts a choice— to land or not to land. With minutes to spare, 
Mission Control gave the order. The Apollo 11 landing was about 
the astronauts, Mission Control, software and hardware all working together
as an integrated system of systems. Hamilton’s contributions were essential
to the work of engineers and scientists inspired by President John F. Kennedy’s 
goal to reach the Moon. And her life-saving work 
went far beyond Apollo 11— no bugs were ever found in the in-flight
software for any crewed Apollo missions. After her work on Apollo, Hamilton founded a company that uses 
its unique universal systems language to create breakthroughs 
for systems and software. In 2003, NASA honored her achievements 
with the largest financial award they’d ever given to an individual. And 47 years after her software
first guided astronauts to the moon, Hamilton was awarded 
the Presidential Medal of Freedom for changing the way we think 
about technology.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Correct Option: A

while developing software to support research 
into the new field of chaos theory. Next at MIT's Lincoln Laboratory, Hamilton developed software 
for America’s first air defense system to search for enemy aircraft. But when she heard 
that renowned engineer Charles Draper was looking for help 
sending mankind to the moon, she immediately joined his team. NASA looked to Draper and his group 
of over 400 engineers to invent the first compact 
digital flight computer, the Apollo Guidance Computer. Using input from astronauts, this device would be responsible 
for guiding, navigating and controlling the spacecraft. At a time when unreliable computers 
filled entire rooms, the AGC needed to operate 
without any errors, and fit in one cubic foot of space. Draper divided the lab into two teams, one for designing hardware 
and one for developing software. Hamilton led the team that built 
the on-board flight software for both the Command and Lunar Modules. This work, for which she coined the term
“software engineering," was incredibly high stakes. Human lives were on the line, 
so every program had to be perfect. Margaret’s software needed to quickly
detect unexpected errors and recover from them in real time. But this kind of adaptable program 
was difficult to build, since early software could only process 
jobs in a predetermined order. To solve this problem, Margaret designed her program 
to be “asynchronous,” meaning the software's more important
jobs would interrupt less important ones. Her team assigned every task 
a unique priority to ensure that each job 
occurred in the correct order and at the right time—
regardless of any surprises. After this breakthrough, Margaret realized her software 
could help the astronauts work in an asynchronous environment as well. She designed Priority Displays that would interrupt 
astronaut’s regularly scheduled tasks to warn them of emergencies. The astronaut could then communicate
with Mission Control to determine the best path forward. This marked the first time flight software
communicated directly— and asynchronously— 
with a pilot. It was these fail safes that triggered 
the alarms just before the lunar landing. Buzz Aldrin quickly realized his mistake— he’d inadvertently flipped 
the rendezvous radar switch. This radar would be essential 
on their journey home, but here it was using up 
vital computational resources. Fortunately, the Apollo Guidance Computer
was well equipped to manage this. During the overload, 
the software restart programs allowed only the highest priority jobs 
to be processed— including the programs 
necessary for landing. The Priority Displays 
gave the astronauts a choice— to land or not to land. With minutes to spare, 
Mission Control gave the order. The Apollo 11 landing was about 
the astronauts, Mission Control, software and hardware all working together
as an integrated system of systems. Hamilton’s contributions were essential
to the work of engineers and scientists inspired by President John F. Kennedy’s 
goal to reach the Moon. And her life-saving work 
went far beyond Apollo 11— no bugs were ever found in the in-flight
software for any crewed Apollo missions. After her work on Apollo, Hamilton founded a company that uses 
its unique universal systems language to create breakthroughs 
for systems and software. In 2003, NASA honored her achievements 
with the largest financial award they’d ever given to an individual. And 47 years after her software
first guided astronauts to the moon, Hamilton was awarded 
the Presidential Medal of Freedom for changing the way we think 
about technology.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Margaret Hamilton and other scientists across the country were working to achieve __________’s goal of landing a man on the Moon by the end of the decade (1960s).
Options: A. Charles Draper, B. President John F. Kennedy, C. Neil Armontrong, D. Richard Nixon
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Margaret Hamilton born? Options: A. Paoli, Indiana, B. Massachusetts, C. New York, D. California Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the main challenge Margaret Hamilton's team faced while developing the on-board flight software for the Apollo Guidance Computer? Options: A. To make the software user-friendly for astronauts, B. To ensure the software operated without errors and fit in a limited space, C. To develop software that could process jobs in a predetermined order, D. To create software that could only detect expected errors Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did Margaret Hamilton's software handle unexpected errors? Options: A. By processing jobs in a predetermined order, B. By restarting the entire system, C. By quickly detecting and recovering from them in real-time, D. By ignoring them Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the term coined by Margaret Hamilton for her work on the Apollo Guidance Computer software? Options: A. Software Development, B. Software Engineering, C. Computer Science, D. Systems Analysis Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the cause of the emergency alarm that lit up just before the lunar landing? Options: A. A malfunction in the Apollo Guidance Computer, B. A mistake made by Mission Control, C. Buzz Aldrin inadvertently flipping the rendezvous radar switch, D. A failure in the spacecraft's navigation system Correct Option: C
Question 6: How did the Apollo Guidance Computer manage the overload caused by the rendezvous radar switch? Options: A. By shutting down the entire system, B. By allowing only the highest priority jobs to be processed, C. By ignoring the overload, D. By restarting the system manually Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the significance of Margaret Hamilton's Priority Displays in the Apollo Guidance Computer software? Options: A. They provided astronauts with a list of scheduled tasks, B. They warned astronauts of emergencies and allowed them to communicate with Mission Control, C. They displayed the spacecraft's navigation data, D. They controlled the spacecraft's altitude Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the outcome of Margaret Hamilton's work on the Apollo Guidance Computer software? Options: A. The software was never used in any crewed Apollo missions, B. The software was found to have several bugs, C. No bugs were ever found in the in-flight software for any crewed Apollo missions, D. The software was only used in the Apollo 11 mission Correct Option: C
Question 9: How did Margaret Hamilton's work on the Apollo Guidance Computer software contribute to the success of the Apollo 11 mission? Options: A. Her software ensured the spacecraft's navigation system functioned correctly, B. Her software managed the overload caused by the rendezvous radar switch, allowing the mission to proceed, C. Her software provided astronauts with a list of scheduled tasks, D. Her software controlled the spacecraft's altitude Correct Option: B
Question 10: What award did Margaret Hamilton receive in 2016 for her contributions to the field of technology? Options: A. Presidential Medal of Freedom, B. NASA Exceptional Service Medal, C. National Medal of Technology, D. Draper Prize Correct Option: A

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A woman in rags emerged from the swamp
flanked by seven giant scorpions. Carrying a baby, she headed 
for the nearest village to beg for food. She approached a magnificent mansion, but the mistress of the house 
took one look at her grimy clothes and unusual companions 
and slammed the door in her face. So she continued down the road 
until she came to a cottage. The woman there took pity on the stranger
and offered her what she could: a simple meal and a bed of straw. Her guest was no ordinary beggar. She was Isis, 
the most powerful goddess in Egypt. Isis was in hiding from her brother Set, who murdered her husband and wanted 
to murder her infant son, Horus. Set was also a powerful god, 
and he was looking for them. So to keep her cover, 
Isis had to be very discreet— she couldn’t risk using her powers. But she was not without aid. Serket, goddess of venomous creatures, had sent seven of her fiercest servants 
to guard Isis and her son. As Isis and Horus settled 
into their humble accommodation, the scorpions fumed at how the wealthy
woman had offended their divine mistress. They all combined their venom 
and gave it to one of the seven, Tefen. In the dead of night, 
Tefen crept over to the mansion. As he crawled under the door, he saw the owner’s young son 
sleeping peacefully and gave him a mighty sting. Isis and her hostess were soon awakened
by loud wailing. As they peered out of the doorway 
of the cottage, they saw a mother running 
through the street, weeping as she cradled her son. When Isis recognized the woman 
who had turned her away, she understood what her 
scorpions had done. Isis took the boy in her arms 
and began to recite a powerful spell: "O poison of Tefen, come out of him 
and fall upon the ground! Poison of Befen, advance not, 
penetrate no farther, come out of him, and fall upon the ground! For I am Isis, the great Enchantress, 
the Speaker of spells. Fall down, O poison of Mestet! 
Hasten not, poison of Mestetef! Rise not, poison of Petet and Thetet! 
Approach not, poison of Matet!" With each name she invoked, 
that scorpion’s poison was neutralized. The child stirred, 
and his mother wept with gratitude and lamented her earlier callousness, offering all her wealth 
to Isis in repentance. The woman who had taken Isis in 
watched in awe— she had had no idea who she’d brought
under her roof. And from that day on, the people learned to make a poultice 
to treat scorpion bites, speaking magical incantations 
just as the goddess had.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where was Isis hiding?
Options: A. Swamp, B. Desert, C. River
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Isis carrying with her when she emerged from the swamp? Options: A. A bag of food, B. A baby, C. A magical spellbook, D. A container of venom Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why did the mistress of the mansion slam the door in Isis' face? Options: A. She was afraid of Isis' powers, B. She was offended by Isis' unusual companions, C. She was repelled by Isis' grimy clothes, D. Both B and C Correct Option: D
Question 3: If you were in a situation where you had to help someone in need, but they appeared dirty and unusual, what would be the most compassionate response? Options: A. Turn them away to avoid any potential danger, B. Offer them food and shelter, but keep a safe distance, C. Take pity on them and offer what you can, like the woman in the cottage, D. Call for external help, such as the authorities Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the relationship between Isis and Set? Options: A. They were husband and wife, B. They were brother and sister, C. They were friends, D. They were enemies, but not related Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why did the scorpions combine their venom and give it to Tefen? Options: A. To protect Isis and Horus from Set, B. To punish the wealthy woman for offending Isis, C. To test Isis' powers, D. To harm the woman who took Isis in Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the result of Isis reciting the powerful spell to neutralize the poison? Options: A. The child died, B. The poison spread to others, C. The child was healed, and the poison fell to the ground, D. The scorpions became more aggressive Correct Option: C
Question 7: What lesson did the people learn from this experience? Options: A. To always turn away strangers in need, B. To be afraid of scorpions and their venom, C. To make a poultice to treat scorpion bites, using magical incantations, D. To never help someone who appears dirty and unusual Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the significance of Isis invoking the names of the scorpions in her spell? Options: A. It was a way to summon more scorpions, B. It was a way to neutralize the poison of each scorpion, C. It was a way to punish the scorpions, D. It was a way to show off her powers Correct Option: B
Question 9: How did the woman who took Isis in initially perceive her guest? Options: A. She knew Isis was a powerful goddess, B. She suspected Isis was in hiding from someone, C. She thought Isis was an ordinary beggar, D. She was afraid of Isis and her scorpions Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the moral of the story regarding the treatment of strangers in need? Options: A. One should always prioritize one's own safety and well-being, B. One should be cautious when helping strangers, but also show compassion, C. One should always turn away strangers who appear dirty and unusual, D. One should only help those who are wealthy and powerful Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, Question 1 mentions Isis emerging from the swamp, which is related to the ground truth MCQ. 

Although it doesn't directly ask where Isis was hiding, it implies the location. Therefore, the most similar generated MCQ would be Question 1.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

**Transcript**:
A woman in rags emerged from the swamp
flanked by seven giant scorpions. Carrying a baby, she headed 
for the nearest village to beg for food. She approached a magnificent mansion, but the mistress of the house 
took one look at her grimy clothes and unusual companions 
and slammed the door in her face. So she continued down the road 
until she came to a cottage. The woman there took pity on the stranger
and offered her what she could: a simple meal and a bed of straw. Her guest was no ordinary beggar. She was Isis, 
the most powerful goddess in Egypt. Isis was in hiding from her brother Set, who murdered her husband and wanted 
to murder her infant son, Horus. Set was also a powerful god, 
and he was looking for them. So to keep her cover, 
Isis had to be very discreet— she couldn’t risk using her powers. But she was not without aid. Serket, goddess of venomous creatures, had sent seven of her fiercest servants 
to guard Isis and her son. As Isis and Horus settled 
into their humble accommodation, the scorpions fumed at how the wealthy
woman had offended their divine mistress. They all combined their venom 
and gave it to one of the seven, Tefen. In the dead of night, 
Tefen crept over to the mansion. As he crawled under the door, he saw the owner’s young son 
sleeping peacefully and gave him a mighty sting. Isis and her hostess were soon awakened
by loud wailing. As they peered out of the doorway 
of the cottage, they saw a mother running 
through the street, weeping as she cradled her son. When Isis recognized the woman 
who had turned her away, she understood what her 
scorpions had done. Isis took the boy in her arms 
and began to recite a powerful spell: "O poison of Tefen, come out of him 
and fall upon the ground! Poison of Befen, advance not, 
penetrate no farther, come out of him, and fall upon the ground! For I am Isis, the great Enchantress, 
the Speaker of spells. Fall down, O poison of Mestet! 
Hasten not, poison of Mestetef! Rise not, poison of Petet and Thetet! 
Approach not, poison of Matet!" With each name she invoked, 
that scorpion’s poison was neutralized. The child stirred, 
and his mother wept with gratitude and lamented her earlier callousness, offering all her wealth 
to Isis in repentance. The woman who had taken Isis in 
watched in awe— she had had no idea who she’d brought
under her roof. And from that day on, the people learned to make a poultice 
to treat scorpion bites, speaking magical incantations 
just as the goddess had.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A woman in rags emerged from the swamp
flanked by seven giant scorpions. Carrying a baby, she headed 
for the nearest village to beg for food. She approached a magnificent mansion, but the mistress of the house 
took one look at her grimy clothes and unusual companions 
and slammed the door in her face. So she continued down the road 
until she came to a cottage. The woman there took pity on the stranger
and offered her what she could: a simple meal and a bed of straw. Her guest was no ordinary beggar. She was Isis, 
the most powerful goddess in Egypt. Isis was in hiding from her brother Set, who murdered her husband and wanted 
to murder her infant son, Horus. Set was also a powerful god, 
and he was looking for them. So to keep her cover, 
Isis had to be very discreet— she couldn’t risk using her powers. But she was not without aid. Serket, goddess of venomous creatures, had sent seven of her fiercest servants 
to guard Isis and her son. As Isis and Horus settled 
into their humble accommodation, the scorpions fumed at how the wealthy
woman had offended their divine mistress. They all combined their venom 
and gave it to one of the seven, Tefen. In the dead of night,

and fall upon the ground! Poison of Befen, advance not,

the Speaker of spells. Fall down, O poison of Mestet!

that scorpion’s poison was neutralized. The child stirred,

to Isis in repentance. The woman who had taken Isis in 
watched in awe— she had had no idea who she’d brought
under her roof. And from that day on, the people learned to make a poultice 
to treat scorpion bites, speaking magical incantations 
just as the goddess had.

Options: A. Petet, B. Befen, C. Tefen
Correct Option: C

Question 2: Why did the mistress of the mansion slam the door in Isis' face? Options: A. She was afraid of Isis' powers, B. She was offended by Isis' unusual companions, C. She was repelled by Isis' grimy clothes, D. Both B and C Correct Option: D
Question 3: If you were in a situation where you had to help someone in need, but they appeared dirty and unusual, what would be the most compassionate response? Options: A. Turn them away to avoid any potential danger, B. Offer them food and shelter, but keep a safe distance, C. Take pity on them and offer what you can, like the woman in the cottage, D. Call for external help, such as the authorities Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the relationship between Isis and Set? Options: A. They were husband and wife, B. They were brother and sister, C. They were friends, D. They were enemies, but not related Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why did the scorpions combine their venom and give it to Tefen? Options: A. To protect Isis and Horus from Set, B. To punish the wealthy woman for offending Isis, C. To test Isis' powers, D. To harm the woman who took Isis in Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the result of Isis reciting the powerful spell to neutralize the poison? Options: A. The child died, B. The poison spread to others, C. The child was healed, and the poison fell to the ground, D. The scorpions became more aggressive Correct Option: C
Question 7: What lesson did the people learn from this experience? Options: A. To always turn away strangers in need, B. To be afraid of scorpions and their venom, C. To make a poultice to treat scorpion bites, using magical incantations, D. To never help someone who appears dirty and unusual Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the significance of Isis invoking the names of the scorpions in her spell? Options: A. It was a way to summon more scorpions, B. It was a way to neutralize the poison of each scorpion, C. It was a way to punish the scorpions, D. It was a way to show off her powers Correct Option: B
Question 9: How did the woman who took Isis in initially perceive her guest? Options: A. She knew Isis was a powerful goddess, B. She suspected Isis was in hiding from someone, C. She thought Isis was an ordinary beggar, D. She was afraid of Isis and her scorpions Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the moral of the story regarding the treatment of strangers in need? Options: A. One should always prioritize one's own safety and well-being, B. One should be cautious when helping strangers, but also show compassion, C. One should always turn away strangers who appear dirty and unusual, D. One should only help those who are wealthy and powerful Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 5: Why did the scorpions combine their venom and give it to Tefen?**

However, this question does not directly match the ground truth MCQ. A more similar question would be one that asks about the scorpion that received the venom of all the others.

Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. But if I had to choose one based on the content and intent, I would say that Question 5 is the closest, although it's not a direct match.

If I had to provide an index, I would say: **5**

However, please note that this is not a direct match, and a more accurate match would be a question that specifically asks about the scorpion that received the venom of all the others, which is not present in the generated MCQs.

To create a more similar MCQ, you could rephrase Question 5 to something like:

**Question: Which scorpion received the combined venom of all the others?**

Options: A. Petet, B. Befen, C. Tefen

Correct Option: C

This revised question would be a more direct match to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A woman in rags emerged from the swamp
flanked by seven giant scorpions. Carrying a baby, she headed 
for the nearest village to beg for food. She approached a magnificent mansion, but the mistress of the house 
took one look at her grimy clothes and unusual companions 
and slammed the door in her face. So she continued down the road 
until she came to a cottage. The woman there took pity on the stranger
and offered her what she could: a simple meal and a bed of straw. Her guest was no ordinary beggar. She was Isis, 
the most powerful goddess in Egypt. Isis was in hiding from her brother Set, who murdered her husband and wanted 
to murder her infant son, Horus. Set was also a powerful god, 
and he was looking for them. So to keep her cover, 
Isis had to be very discreet— she couldn’t risk using her powers. But she was not without aid. Serket, goddess of venomous creatures, had sent seven of her fiercest servants 
to guard Isis and her son. As Isis and Horus settled 
into their humble accommodation, the scorpions fumed at how the wealthy
woman had offended their divine mistress. They all combined their venom 
and gave it to one of the seven, Tefen. In the dead of night, 
Tefen crept over to the mansion. As he crawled under the door, he saw the owner’s young son 
sleeping peacefully and gave him a mighty sting. Isis and her hostess were soon awakened
by loud wailing. As they peered out of the doorway 
of the cottage, they saw a mother running 
through the street, weeping as she cradled her son. When Isis recognized the woman 
who had turned her away, she understood what her 
scorpions had done. Isis took the boy in her arms 
and began to recite a powerful spell: "O poison of Tefen, come out of him 
and fall upon the ground! Poison of Befen, advance not, 
penetrate no farther, come out of him, and fall upon the ground! For I am Isis, the great Enchantress, 
the Speaker of spells. Fall down, O poison of Mestet! 
Hasten not, poison of Mestetef! Rise not, poison of Petet and Thetet! 
Approach not, poison of Matet!" With each name she invoked, 
that scorpion’s poison was neutralized. The child stirred, 
and his mother wept with gratitude and lamented her earlier callousness, offering all her wealth 
to Isis in repentance. The woman who had taken Isis in 
watched in awe— she had had no idea who she’d brought
under her roof. And from that day on, the people learned to make a poultice 
to treat scorpion bites, speaking magical incantations 
just as the goddess had.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How did Isis neutralize the scorpions’ venom?
Options: A. By calling their divine names, B. By killing the scorpions, C. By purifying the child in fire
Correct Option: A

Question 6: What was the result of Isis reciting the powerful spell to neutralize the poison? Options: A. The child died, B. The poison spread to others, C. The child was healed, and the poison fell to the ground, D. The scorpions became more aggressive Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 2013, a team of researchers 
held a math test. The exam was administered 
to over 1,100 American adults, and designed, in part, to test 
their ability to evaluate sets of data. Hidden among these math problems 
were two almost identical questions. Both problems 
used the same difficult data set, and each had one objectively 
correct answer. The first asked about the correlation 
between rashes and a new skin cream. The second asked about the correlation 
between crime rates and gun control legislation. Participants with strong math skills were much more likely 
to get the first question correct. But despite being 
mathematically identical, the results for the second question 
looked totally different. Here, math skills 
weren’t the best predictor of which participants answered correctly. Instead, another variable the researchers 
had been tracking came into play: political identity. Participants whose political beliefs aligned with a correct interpretation 
of the data were far more likely 
to answer the problem right. Even the study’s top mathematicians were 45% more likely 
to get the second question wrong when the correct answer 
challenged their political beliefs. What is it about politics that inspires 
this kind of illogical error? Can someone’s political identity 
actually affect their ability to process information? The answer lies in a cognitive phenomenon that has become increasingly visible 
in public life: partisanship. While it’s often invoked 
in the context of politics, partisanship is more broadly defined 
as a strong preference or bias towards any particular group or idea. Our political, ethnic, religious, 
and national identities are all different forms of partisanship. Of course, identifying with social groups is an essential and healthy part 
of human life. Our sense of self is defined not only by 
who we are as individuals, but also by the groups we belong to. As a result, we’re strongly motivated 
to defend our group identities, protecting both our sense of self 
and our social communities. But this becomes a problem 
when the group’s beliefs are at odds with reality. Imagine watching your favorite sports team
commit a serious foul. You know that’s against the rules, but your fellow fans 
think it’s totally acceptable. The tension between 
these two incompatible thoughts is called cognitive dissonance, and most people are driven to resolve 
this uncomfortable state of limbo. You might start to blame the referee, 
complain that the other team started it, or even convince yourself 
there was no foul in the first place. In a case like this, people are often more motivated 
to maintain a positive relationship with their group 
than perceive the world accurately. This behavior 
is especially dangerous in politics. On an individual scale, allegiance to a party allows people 
to create a political identity and support policies they agree with. But partisan-based cognitive dissonance 
can lead people to reject evidence that’s inconsistent with the party line 
or discredits party leaders. And when entire groups of people revise 
the facts in service of partisan beliefs, it can lead to policies 
that aren’t grounded in truth or reason. This problem isn’t new— political identities 
have been around for centuries. But studies show 
that partisan polarization has increased dramatically 
in the last few decades. One theory explaining this increase is the trend towards clustering 
geographically in like-minded communities. Another is the growing tendency 
to rely on partisan news or social media bubbles. These often act like echo chambers, delivering news and ideas 
from people with similar views. Fortunately, cognitive scientists 
have uncovered some strategies for resisting this distortion filter. One is to remember that you’re probably 
more biased than you think. So when you encounter new information, make a deliberate effort 
to push through your initial intuition and evaluate it analytically. In your own groups, try to make 
fact-checking and questioning assumptions a valued part of the culture. Warning people that they might have been 
presented with misinformation can also help. And when you’re trying 
to persuade someone else, affirming their values 
and framing the issue in their language can help make people more receptive. We still have a long way to go before 
solving the problem of partisanship. But hopefully, these tools 
can help keep us better informed, and capable of making evidence-based 
decisions about our shared reality.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In 2013 a team of researchers examined how people solved identical math problems about non-political (skin cream) and political (gun control) topics. Which problems were most difficult for people?
Options: A. Non-political topics, B. Political topics, C. Both were equal
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary goal of the math test administered to over 1,100 American adults in 2013? Options: A. To test their ability to evaluate sets of data, B. To assess their knowledge of politics, C. To measure their math skills, D. To analyze their cognitive dissonance Correct Option: A
Question 2: What factor significantly influenced participants' answers to the second question about crime rates and gun control legislation? Options: A. Math skills, B. Political identity, C. Age, D. Education level Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is partisanship broadly defined as? Options: A. A strong preference or bias towards any particular group or idea, B. A neutral stance on politics, C. A lack of identity with social groups, D. A rational evaluation of evidence Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the term for the tension between two incompatible thoughts, such as when a person's group identity conflicts with reality? Options: A. Cognitive dissonance, B. Partisan polarization, C. Confirmation bias, D. Social identity theory Correct Option: A
Question 5: Why do people often reject evidence that is inconsistent with their party's beliefs? Options: A. Because they are motivated to maintain a positive relationship with their group, B. Because they are driven by a desire for truth and reason, C. Because they are uninformed about the issues, D. Because they are apathetic about politics Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one theory explaining the increase in partisan polarization in recent decades? Options: A. The trend towards clustering geographically in like-minded communities, B. The growing tendency to rely on objective news sources, C. The decrease in social media usage, D. The increase in bipartisan cooperation Correct Option: A
Question 7: What strategy can help individuals resist the distortion filter of partisanship? Options: A. Relying solely on intuition when evaluating new information, B. Making a deliberate effort to push through initial intuition and evaluate information analytically, C. Ignoring information that challenges one's group identity, D. Surrounding oneself with people who share similar views Correct Option: B
Question 8: How can affirming someone's values and framing an issue in their language help in persuasion? Options: A. By making them more defensive and resistant to change, B. By making them more receptive to new information, C. By ignoring their concerns and values, D. By dismissing their perspective Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the potential consequence of entire groups of people revising facts in service of partisan beliefs? Options: A. Policies that are grounded in truth and reason, B. Increased bipartisan cooperation, C. More informed decision-making, D. Policies that are not grounded in truth or reason Correct Option: D
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is essential for keeping people better informed and capable of making evidence-based decisions? Options: A. Relying solely on partisan news sources, B. Surrounding oneself with people who share similar views, C. Using tools and strategies to resist the distortion filter of partisanship, D. Ignoring information that challenges one's group identity Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, as it discusses the same study and the factor that influenced participants' answers to the question about crime rates and gun control legislation. The options in Question 2 also align with the ground truth MCQ, as they include the correct answer (political identity) and plausible distractors (math skills, age, and education level). The intent of Question 2 is also similar to the ground truth MCQ, as it aims to assess the test-taker's understanding of how political identity can affect people's ability to process information.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

can help keep us better informed, and capable of making evidence-based 
decisions about our shared reality.

Options: A. They both love sports, B. Blame the referee, C. They both identify with groups, D. They are both rational
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When your favorite sports team breaks the rules by committing a serious foul against the other team, it can create an uncomfortable feeling called cognitive dissonance. How can you reduce this feeling?
Options: A. Convince yourself there was no foul, B. Blame the referee, C. Assume the other team was an instigator, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary goal of the math test administered to over 1,100 American adults in 2013? Options: A. To test their ability to evaluate sets of data, B. To assess their knowledge of politics, C. To measure their math skills, D. To analyze their cognitive dissonance Correct Option: A
Question 2: What factor significantly influenced participants' answers to the second question about crime rates and gun control legislation? Options: A. Math skills, B. Political identity, C. Age, D. Education level Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is partisanship broadly defined as? Options: A. A strong preference or bias towards any particular group or idea, B. A neutral stance on politics, C. A lack of identity with social groups, D. A rational evaluation of evidence Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the term for the tension between two incompatible thoughts, such as when a person's group identity conflicts with reality? Options: A. Cognitive dissonance, B. Partisan polarization, C. Confirmation bias, D. Social identity theory Correct Option: A
Question 5: Why do people often reject evidence that is inconsistent with their party's beliefs? Options: A. Because they are motivated to maintain a positive relationship with their group, B. Because they are driven by a desire for truth and reason, C. Because they are uninformed about the issues, D. Because they are apathetic about politics Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one theory explaining the increase in partisan polarization in recent decades? Options: A. The trend towards clustering geographically in like-minded communities, B. The growing tendency to rely on objective news sources, C. The decrease in social media usage, D. The increase in bipartisan cooperation Correct Option: A
Question 7: What strategy can help individuals resist the distortion filter of partisanship? Options: A. Relying solely on intuition when evaluating new information, B. Making a deliberate effort to push through initial intuition and evaluate information analytically, C. Ignoring information that challenges one's group identity, D. Surrounding oneself with people who share similar views Correct Option: B
Question 8: How can affirming someone's values and framing an issue in their language help in persuasion? Options: A. By making them more defensive and resistant to change, B. By making them more receptive to new information, C. By ignoring their concerns and values, D. By dismissing their perspective Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the potential consequence of entire groups of people revising facts in service of partisan beliefs? Options: A. Policies that are grounded in truth and reason, B. Increased bipartisan cooperation, C. More informed decision-making, D. Policies that are not grounded in truth or reason Correct Option: D
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is essential for keeping people better informed and capable of making evidence-based decisions? Options: A. Relying solely on partisan news sources, B. Surrounding oneself with people who share similar views, C. Using tools and strategies to resist the distortion filter of partisanship, D. Ignoring information that challenges one's group identity Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

Although the question stems are not identical, both questions deal with the concept of cognitive dissonance. The ground truth MCQ asks how one can reduce the feeling of cognitive dissonance when their favorite sports team breaks the rules, while Generated MCQ 4 asks about the term for the tension between two incompatible thoughts, such as when a person's group identity conflicts with reality.

However, a closer examination of the options in Generated MCQs reveals that none directly match the options in the ground truth MCQ. Nevertheless, Generated MCQ 4 is the most similar in terms of content and intent.

If I had to choose an answer based solely on the provided generated MCQs, I would select Question 4 as the closest match, despite the differences in question stems and options.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 2013, a team of researchers 
held a math test. The exam was administered 
to over 1,100 American adults, and designed, in part, to test 
their ability to evaluate sets of data. Hidden among these math problems 
were two almost identical questions. Both problems 
used the same difficult data set, and each had one objectively 
correct answer. The first asked about the correlation 
between rashes and a new skin cream. The second asked about the correlation 
between crime rates and gun control legislation. Participants with strong math skills were much more likely 
to get the first question correct. But despite being 
mathematically identical, the results for the second question 
looked totally different. Here, math skills 
weren’t the best predictor of which participants answered correctly. Instead, another variable the researchers 
had been tracking came into play: political identity. Participants whose political beliefs aligned with a correct interpretation 
of the data were far more likely 
to answer the problem right. Even the study’s top mathematicians were 45% more likely 
to get the second question wrong when the correct answer 
challenged their political beliefs. What is it about politics that inspires 
this kind of illogical error? Can someone’s political identity 
actually affect their ability to process information? The answer lies in a cognitive phenomenon that has become increasingly visible 
in public life: partisanship. While it’s often invoked 
in the context of politics, partisanship is more broadly defined 
as a strong preference or bias towards any particular group or idea. Our political, ethnic, religious, 
and national identities are all different forms of partisanship. Of course, identifying with social groups is an essential and healthy part 
of human life. Our sense of self is defined not only by 
who we are as individuals, but also by the groups we belong to. As a result, we’re strongly motivated 
to defend our group identities, protecting both our sense of self 
and our social communities. But this becomes a problem 
when the group’s beliefs are at odds with reality. Imagine watching your favorite sports team
commit a serious foul. You know that’s against the rules, but your fellow fans 
think it’s totally acceptable. The tension between 
these two incompatible thoughts is called cognitive dissonance, and most people are driven to resolve 
this uncomfortable state of limbo. You might start to blame the referee, 
complain that the other team started it, or even convince yourself 
there was no foul in the first place. In a case like this, people are often more motivated 
to maintain a positive relationship with their group 
than perceive the world accurately. This behavior 
is especially dangerous in politics. On an individual scale, allegiance to a party allows people 
to create a political identity and support policies they agree with. But partisan-based cognitive dissonance 
can lead people to reject evidence that’s inconsistent with the party line 
or discredits party leaders. And when entire groups of people revise 
the facts in service of partisan beliefs, it can lead to policies 
that aren’t grounded in truth or reason. This problem isn’t new— political identities 
have been around for centuries. But studies show 
that partisan polarization has increased dramatically 
in the last few decades. One theory explaining this increase is the trend towards clustering 
geographically in like-minded communities. Another is the growing tendency 
to rely on partisan news or social media bubbles. These often act like echo chambers, delivering news and ideas 
from people with similar views. Fortunately, cognitive scientists 
have uncovered some strategies for resisting this distortion filter. One is to remember that you’re probably 
more biased than you think. So when you encounter new information, make a deliberate effort 
to push through your initial intuition and evaluate it analytically. In your own groups, try to make 
fact-checking and questioning assumptions a valued part of the culture. Warning people that they might have been 
presented with misinformation can also help. And when you’re trying 
to persuade someone else, affirming their values 
and framing the issue in their language can help make people more receptive. We still have a long way to go before 
solving the problem of partisanship. But hopefully, these tools 
can help keep us better informed, and capable of making evidence-based 
decisions about our shared reality.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How can you help persuade someone from another group?
Options: A. Insult their intelligence, B. Use their language, C. Argue with them, D. Publicly shame them
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary goal of the math test administered to over 1,100 American adults in 2013? Options: A. To test their ability to evaluate sets of data, B. To assess their knowledge of politics, C. To measure their math skills, D. To analyze their cognitive dissonance Correct Option: A
Question 2: What factor significantly influenced participants' answers to the second question about crime rates and gun control legislation? Options: A. Math skills, B. Political identity, C. Age, D. Education level Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is partisanship broadly defined as? Options: A. A strong preference or bias towards any particular group or idea, B. A neutral stance on politics, C. A lack of identity with social groups, D. A rational evaluation of evidence Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the term for the tension between two incompatible thoughts, such as when a person's group identity conflicts with reality? Options: A. Cognitive dissonance, B. Partisan polarization, C. Confirmation bias, D. Social identity theory Correct Option: A
Question 5: Why do people often reject evidence that is inconsistent with their party's beliefs? Options: A. Because they are motivated to maintain a positive relationship with their group, B. Because they are driven by a desire for truth and reason, C. Because they are uninformed about the issues, D. Because they are apathetic about politics Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one theory explaining the increase in partisan polarization in recent decades? Options: A. The trend towards clustering geographically in like-minded communities, B. The growing tendency to rely on objective news sources, C. The decrease in social media usage, D. The increase in bipartisan cooperation Correct Option: A
Question 7: What strategy can help individuals resist the distortion filter of partisanship? Options: A. Relying solely on intuition when evaluating new information, B. Making a deliberate effort to push through initial intuition and evaluate information analytically, C. Ignoring information that challenges one's group identity, D. Surrounding oneself with people who share similar views Correct Option: B
Question 8: How can affirming someone's values and framing an issue in their language help in persuasion? Options: A. By making them more defensive and resistant to change, B. By making them more receptive to new information, C. By ignoring their concerns and values, D. By dismissing their perspective Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the potential consequence of entire groups of people revising facts in service of partisan beliefs? Options: A. Policies that are grounded in truth and reason, B. Increased bipartisan cooperation, C. More informed decision-making, D. Policies that are not grounded in truth or reason Correct Option: D
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is essential for keeping people better informed and capable of making evidence-based decisions? Options: A. Relying solely on partisan news sources, B. Surrounding oneself with people who share similar views, C. Using tools and strategies to resist the distortion filter of partisanship, D. Ignoring information that challenges one's group identity Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ in terms of intent, options, and content. Both questions focus on how to effectively persuade someone from another group, and both suggest that using the person's language or framing the issue in a way that resonates with their values can be an effective strategy. The correct options in both questions (B. Use their language and B. By making them more receptive to new information) convey the same idea, which is to approach the person in a way that is respectful and relatable to their perspective.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 2013, a team of researchers 
held a math test. The exam was administered 
to over 1,100 American adults, and designed, in part, to test 
their ability to evaluate sets of data. Hidden among these math problems 
were two almost identical questions. Both problems 
used the same difficult data set, and each had one objectively 
correct answer. The first asked about the correlation 
between rashes and a new skin cream. The second asked about the correlation 
between crime rates and gun control legislation. Participants with strong math skills were much more likely 
to get the first question correct. But despite being 
mathematically identical, the results for the second question 
looked totally different. Here, math skills 
weren’t the best predictor of which participants answered correctly. Instead, another variable the researchers 
had been tracking came into play: political identity. Participants whose political beliefs aligned with a correct interpretation 
of the data were far more likely 
to answer the problem right. Even the study’s top mathematicians were 45% more likely 
to get the second question wrong when the correct answer 
challenged their political beliefs. What is it about politics that inspires 
this kind of illogical error? Can someone’s political identity 
actually affect their ability to process information? The answer lies in a cognitive phenomenon that has become increasingly visible 
in public life: partisanship. While it’s often invoked 
in the context of politics, partisanship is more broadly defined 
as a strong preference or bias towards any particular group or idea. Our political, ethnic, religious, 
and national identities are all different forms of partisanship. Of course, identifying with social groups is an essential and healthy part 
of human life. Our sense of self is defined not only by 
who we are as individuals, but also by the groups we belong to. As a result, we’re strongly motivated 
to defend our group identities, protecting both our sense of self 
and our social communities. But this becomes a problem 
when the group’s beliefs are at odds with reality. Imagine watching your favorite sports team
commit a serious foul. You know that’s against the rules, but your fellow fans 
think it’s totally acceptable. The tension between 
these two incompatible thoughts is called cognitive dissonance, and most people are driven to resolve 
this uncomfortable state of limbo. You might start to blame the referee, 
complain that the other team started it, or even convince yourself 
there was no foul in the first place. In a case like this, people are often more motivated 
to maintain a positive relationship with their group 
than perceive the world accurately. This behavior 
is especially dangerous in politics. On an individual scale, allegiance to a party allows people 
to create a political identity and support policies they agree with. But partisan-based cognitive dissonance 
can lead people to reject evidence that’s inconsistent with the party line 
or discredits party leaders. And when entire groups of people revise 
the facts in service of partisan beliefs, it can lead to policies 
that aren’t grounded in truth or reason. This problem isn’t new— political identities 
have been around for centuries. But studies show 
that partisan polarization has increased dramatically 
in the last few decades. One theory explaining this increase is the trend towards clustering 
geographically in like-minded communities. Another is the growing tendency 
to rely on partisan news or social media bubbles. These often act like echo chambers, delivering news and ideas 
from people with similar views. Fortunately, cognitive scientists 
have uncovered some strategies for resisting this distortion filter. One is to remember that you’re probably 
more biased than you think. So when you encounter new information, make a deliberate effort 
to push through your initial intuition and evaluate it analytically. In your own groups, try to make 
fact-checking and questioning assumptions a valued part of the culture. Warning people that they might have been 
presented with misinformation can also help. And when you’re trying 
to persuade someone else, affirming their values 
and framing the issue in their language can help make people more receptive. We still have a long way to go before 
solving the problem of partisanship. But hopefully, these tools 
can help keep us better informed, and capable of making evidence-based 
decisions about our shared reality.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which strategy will help you resist the distortion filter of identity?
Options: A. Engage in analytic thinking, B. Fact check information, C. Understand your own biases, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Because they are driven by a desire for truth and reason, C. Because they are uninformed about the issues, D. Because they are apathetic about politics Correct Option: A
